facts.text: Jangi Jogi inherited properties consisting of some groves and a house in village Mukupdpur in the erstwhile State of Rewa which later became part of Madhya Pradesh.
Jangi Jogi had a son Laldas who died in 1945 leaving the appellant, his widow, as his heir and legal representative.
After the death of Laldas, Jangi Jogi married Mst. Jugli Bai in 1948.

Respondent No. 1 raised a claim to the properties of Jangi Jogi by virtue of a gift deed and moved criminal courts under S. 145 Cr.P.C.; on December 29, 1962 an order was made directing possession to be delivered to respondent No. 1.
Appellant instituted suit in Civil Judge at Rewa along with Jugli Bai for declaration of rights and possession of properties.
Respondent No. 1 claimed continuous possession for more than 12 years and ownership; alternatively, Jugli Bai had interest but her thumb impression on plaint obtained by fraud.
During pendency, plaintiff No. 2 Jugli Bai entered compromise with respondent No. 1 giving up claims.

Trial court found thumb impression of Jugli Bai not obtained by fraud but she changed sides; no gift deed made by Jangi Jogi; appellant in possession until dispossessed by respondent No. 1 via S. 145 Cr.P.C.; respondent illegally occupied and was trespasser; but dismissed suit as estate devolved on Jugli Bai who compromised.
District Judge set aside trial court decree, held compromise not binding on appellant, trial court did not decide all issues, remanded for fresh disposal.

High Court dismissed appeal of appellant, held she had no interest citing Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937 s. 3(2) and Umayal Achi case; compromise valid under O.23 r.3 CPC; respondent clothed with Jugli Bai's rights.
Jugli Bai filed application under O.23 r.1 CPC on February 19, 1959 withdrawing her claim and suit to extent of her claim, filing compromise with defendant.
Application under O.23 r.3 CPC filed stating suit of plaintiff No. 2 be dismissed, no relief to her.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant, widow of predeceased son, had interest or right to possession of properties left by Jangi Jogi under Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937.
Whether compromise by Jugli Bai adversely affected appellant's rights and entitled dismissal of suit.
Whether appellant entitled to restoration of possession from respondent No. 1 found to be trespasser, given her possession in lieu of maintenance.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant in possession until dispossessed by trespass; entitled to restoration from trespasser.
Entitled to maintenance from father-in-law's estate; possession in lieu thereof; could take boy in adoption vesting rights retrospectively.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu Women's Rights to Property Act 1937; Hindu Adoption and Maintenance Act 1956 s.19

petitioner_arguments.text: Compromise by Jugli Bai not binding on appellant who was not party.

respondent_arguments.text: Continuous possession over 12 years perfecting title; gift deed from Jangi Jogi.
Jugli Bai sole heir; compromise valid under O.23 r.3 CPC; transfers rights to respondent.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant entitled to maintenance from father-in-law's estate; possession in lieu not defeatable by Jugli Bai or trespasser without securing maintenance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to maintenance not liable to defeat except by bona fide purchaser; courts protect widow's possession for maintenance.

court_reasoning.text: Applications under O.23 r.1 and r.3 only withdrew Jugli Bai's claim; could not dismiss appellant's suit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Compromise did not adversely affect appellant as she had no right per High Court, but possession rights exist independently.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant had possessory title against trespasser respondent; entitled to declaration and restoration per Privy Council in Ismail Ariff.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Possession sufficient evidence of title against wrong-doer; High Court erred in holding respondent clothed with Jugli Bai's rights.

holdings.text: Widow of predeceased son entitled to maintenance and possession in lieu thereof from father-in-law's estate until remarriage or proper provision made.
Compromise by Jugli Bai withdrawing her claim does not dismiss co-plaintiff appellant's suit or transfer rights to trespasser.
Plaintiff with possession entitled to restoration against trespasser lacking title.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied to deny s.3(2) rights to widow of predeceased son
Purchaser with notice not entitled to possession without securing maintenance for widow in possession
Settled practice not to allow heir to recover property from maintenance widow without securing maintenance
Possession proves title against wrong-doer; entitled to declaration and injunction

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgment of Madhya Pradesh High Court set aside and that of District Judge restored; case remanded for fresh decision as per District Judge; costs awarded to appellant in Supreme Court and High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Reversal of High Court; restoration of remand order; costs and court fee recoverable from respondent No. 1
outcome.costs: Costs in Supreme Court and High Court to appellant, recoverable from respondent No. 1; court fee per O.33 r.8 Supreme Court Rules from respondent No. 1

key_quotes.text: "It cannot be disputed that the appellant who is the widow of a predeceased son of Jangi Jogi was entitled to receive maintenance so long as she did not remarry out of the estate of her father-in-law."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The possession of the plaintiff was sufficient evidence of title as owner against the defendant." (Sir Richard Couch, Privy Council)
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "It is difficult to see how on the basis of these applications the suit of the appellant could be dismissed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects dismissal based on Jugli Bai's withdrawal
